objective.description: Rhetorical Knowledge
objective.bfw_description: <p>Adopted by the Council of Writing Program Administrators (WPA), April 2000; amended July 2008.</p><p><br></p><p>For further information about the development of the Outcomes Statement, please see</p><p><br></p><p><a href="http://comppile.org/archives/WPAoutcomes/continue.html" data-mce-href="http://comppile.org/archives/WPAoutcomes/continue.html">http://comppile.org/archives/WPAoutcomes/continue.html</a></p><p><br></p><p>For further information about the Council of Writing Program Administrators, please see</p><p><br></p><p><a href="http://www.wpacouncil.org/" data-mce-href="http://www.wpacouncil.org/">http://www.wpacouncil.org</a></p><p><br></p><p>A version of this statement was published in <em>WPA: Writing Program Administration</em> 23.1/2 (fall/winter 1999): 59-66</p>

objective.description: Focus on a purpose

objective.bfw_description: <p>Adopted by the Council of Writing Program Administrators (WPA), April 2000; amended July 2008.</p><p><br></p><p>For further information about the development of the Outcomes Statement, please see</p><p><br></p><p><a href="http://comppile.org/archives/WPAoutcomes/continue.html" data-mce-href="http://comppile.org/archives/WPAoutcomes/continue.html">http://comppile.org/archives/WPAoutcomes/continue.html</a></p><p><br></p><p>For further information about the Council of Writing Program Administrators, please see</p><p><br></p><p><a href="http://www.wpacouncil.org/" data-mce-href="http://www.wpacouncil.org/">http://www.wpacouncil.org</a></p><p><br></p><p>A version of this statement was published in <em>WPA: Writing Program Administration</em> 23.1/2 (fall/winter 1999): 59-66</p>

objective.description: Locate, evaluate, organize, and use research material collected from electronic sources, including scholarly library databases; other official databases and informal electronic networks and internet sources
objective.bfw_description: <p>Adopted by the Council of Writing Program Administrators (WPA), April 2000; amended July 2008.</p><p><br></p><p>For further information about the development of the Outcomes Statement, please see</p><p><br></p><p><a href="http://comppile.org/archives/WPAoutcomes/continue.html" data-mce-href="http://comppile.org/archives/WPAoutcomes/continue.html">http://comppile.org/archives/WPAoutcomes/continue.html</a></p><p><br></p><p>For further information about the Council of Writing Program Administrators, please see</p><p><br></p><p><a href="http://www.wpacouncil.org/" data-mce-href="http://www.wpacouncil.org/">http://www.wpacouncil.org</a></p><p><br></p><p>A version of this statement was published in <em>WPA: Writing Program Administration</em> 23.1/2 (fall/winter 1999): 59-66</p>

objective.description: Understand and exploit the differences in the rhetorical strategies and in the affordances available for both print and electronic composing processes and texts
objective.bfw_description: <p>Adopted by the Council of Writing Program Administrators (WPA), April 2000; amended July 2008.</p><p><br></p><p>For further information about the development of the Outcomes Statement, please see</p><p><br></p><p><a href="http://comppile.org/archives/WPAoutcomes/continue.html" data-mce-href="http://comppile.org/archives/WPAoutcomes/continue.html">http://comppile.org/archives/WPAoutcomes/continue.html</a></p><p><br></p><p>For further information about the Council of Writing Program Administrators, please see</p><p><br></p><p><a href="http://www.wpacouncil.org/" data-mce-href="http://www.wpacouncil.org/">http://www.wpacouncil.org</a></p><p><br></p><p>A version of this statement was published in <em>WPA: Writing Program Administration</em> 23.1/2 (fall/winter 1999): 59-66</p>

data.title: Practical Argument
data.description:
Practical Argument, Second Edition
Laurie G. Kirszner and Stephen R. Mandell
  • About the Book
  • What is Integrated Media
  • Formats and e-Books
  • Writing
  • Instructor Resources

Welcome, instructor. You can create your own version of the Integrated Media for your students. Here’s how it works: Browse and assign from the list of digital content integrated into your book’s table of contents. Activate your course and send the URL to your students so they can join your course. See your students’ progress across all pages and activities.

Here's how it works:
  • Customize your table of contents and build out assignments.
  • Enable student registration and enter your course information.
  • See student activity across the pages and materials in the x-book.
Get into the x-Book

data.title: Marketing Material
data.description:
• About the Book
  • What is Integrated Media
  • Formats and e-Books
  • Writing
  • Instructor Resources

Bedford Media


Practical Argument, Second Edition



Students can
  • log into the Integrated Media for their book
  • (new user register using the code printed in their book)
  • purchase other Format and e-Books
  • use open resources in Re:Writing

Instructor can
  • log into the Integrated Media with instructor access
  • request an exam copy from About the Book
  • learn about other Formats and e-Books
  • download Instructor Resources


Bedford Integrated Media take advantage of what the Web can do.

Students receive access to Bedford Integrated Media with the purchase of new print book or e-book. If the code does not work, It might be expired. Students may purchase access using the "Purchase Access" option on the right.


Practical Argument, Second Edition
Laurie G. Kirszner and Stephen R. Mandell

data.title: Folder
data.description: An organizational tool, which may contain other resources. Most often, an instructor would create a folder to hold related items, such as all links, assets, or files associated with a certain topic, project, or due date.

data.title: Document Collection
data.description:
A repository for useful files, typically those employed in the delivery of course information or material that offers educational support. The collection may be organized, referenced, or assigned by instructors for students to access

Typical Uses
• A location to host course information, policies, or processes.
• A location to host documents related to activities or labs, articles, or worksheets to be used in class.

data.title: HTML Page
data.description:
A flexible blank slate on which an instructor can incorporate any HTML-based content. The page HTML page can incorporate links, images, or active multimedia content. HTML pages within the Portal can be produced through an easy-touse editor.

Typical Uses
• General content such as announcements, policies, explanations

data.title: Quiz
data.description:
An assignment primarily designed to assess knowledge. Quizzes replicate the experience of traditional in-class quizzes, in that they are often timed and do not incorporate support opportunities.

Typical Uses
• Reading verification
• Summative Assessment
